arguments.argument: Transgender athletes should be able to compete in alignment with their gender identity for inclusivity.
Banning transgender athletes from teams of their gender identity is discriminatory.
Sports organizations can implement fair policies to ensure competition remains balanced.
Scientific studies show that hormone therapy reduces biological differences over time.
Excluding transgender athletes can harm their mental health and well-being.
Many sports already have guidelines in place for transgender participation.
Transgender people should not be forced to compete in categories that do not align with their identity.
Equality in sports should be prioritized over outdated gender norms.
Physical differences exist in all athletes, yet they are not used to exclude non-trans competitors.
Denying transgender athletes their rights could set a dangerous precedent for discrimination in other areas.
Biological differences give transgender women an unfair advantage in women's sports.
Transgender participation may undermine the integrity of sex-segregated sports.
Allowing transgender athletes to compete could discourage cisgender women from participating.
Performance differences between biological sexes remain even after hormone therapy.
Fair competition requires physical categories based on biological sex, not gender identity.
Creating additional categories for transgender athletes is a more balanced approach.
Sports records and achievements could become unfairly skewed if biological differences are ignored.
Not all sports organizations have clear policies on how to integrate transgender athletes fairly.
Policies favoring inclusion over fairness could hurt female athletes' opportunities.
Scientific research on the impact of transgender athletes in sports is still evolving, making policy decisions premature.
